questions.text: A 6-month old baby was brought to the clinic with the following finding. Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Oral propranolol can be used for treating this condition

options.label: D
options.text: Most common orbital tumor of children.

questions.explanation:
Description
  • Most common orbital tumor in children (Option D)
  • More common in girls than boys (3:2 ratio) (Option A)

Onset & Growth
  • Visible at birth in about one-third of cases
  • Rapid growth phase in the first 6 months
  • ~75% regress by 7 years old spontaneously (Option B)

Appearance
  • Red, raised nodular mass ("strawberry nevus")
  • Deep orbital mass: proptosis and globe displacement

Histopathology
  • Lobules of plump endothelial cells separated by fibrous septa

 

Management
  • Only done for complicated cases (affecting vision loss, systemic,etc.) and for cosmetic indications.
  • Oral Propranolol (Option C)
  • Intralesional corticosteroid
  • Radiotherapy/Cryotherapy
  • Surgery

Benign Tumors

Papilloma
  • Most common benign tumor arising from surface epithelium

Xanthelasma
  • Middle aged woman, lipid deposits present within histiocytes

Hemangioma
  • Capillary & Cavernous hemangioma

Neurofibroma
  • Variant called Plexiform neurofibroma:
  • S-shaped appearance
  • Bag of worms feel on palpation

Keratoacanthoma
  • Non-pigmented protrusion with keratin filled central crater

Naevi
  • Congenital naevi ; Acquired naevi

 

Pre-Malignant Tumors

Actinic keratosis
  • Over sun-exposed areas

Xeroderma pigmentosum

  • Defective nucleotide excision repair

Malignant Tumors

Basal cell cancer
  • Most common malignant tumor of eyelid
  • Most common site: lower lid > medial canthus

Squamous cell cancer
  • 2nd most common malignant tumor of eyelid

Sebaceous gland carcinoma
  • Recurrence - common

Malignant melanoma
  • Most common type: superficial spreading type
  • Worst prognosis type: Nodular melanoma

questions.text: Match the image with the condition: Image Condition a. Chronic painless swelling 1. Stye b. Acute painful swelling 2. Chalazion c. Acute painful Swelling 3. Hordeolum Internum
questions.explanation:
Condition

Definition & Features

Treatment

Hordeolum externum (Stye)
  • Acute suppurative painful inflammation of a lash follicle and associated glands of Zeis or Moll.
  • Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Symptoms: Acute pain with swelling on the anterior lid margin, watering and photophobia.

 
  • Hot compresses 2-3 times daily.
  • Evacuate pus by epilating involved cilia when pus point forms.
  • Rarely, surgical incision for large abscess.
  • Antibiotic eye drops and ointment.
  • Systemic anti-inflammatory and analgesics.
  • Systemic antibiotics for early infection control.
  • Identify and treat predisposing conditions in recurrent cases.

Hordeolum Internum
  • Acute Suppurative painful inflammation of the meibomian gland with duct blockage.


 
  • Similar to external hordeolum treatment.
  • Drain pus by a vertical incision from the tarsal conjunctiva when pus forms.

Chalazion
  • Chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Painless swelling of the eyelid, mild heaviness, blurred vision.
  • Nodule is present slightly away from the lid margin.
  • Malignant change into meibomian gland adenocarcinoma may be seen in elderly.
  • Conservative treatment: Hot fomentation, topical antibiotics, oral anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Intralesional steroid injection (triamcinolone).
  • Incision (vertical on the conjunctival side, and horizontal on skin side), and curettage for conventional treatment.
  • Diathermy for marginal chalazion.
  • Oral tetracycline as prophylaxis in recurrent cases, especially with acne rosacea or seborrhoeic dermatitis.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing bacterial blepharitis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic infection of the anterior part of the lid margin

Synonyms

  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Staphylococcal blepharitis

Causative Organisms
  • Most commonly Staphylococci (coagulase positive)
  • Rarely Streptococci, Propionibacterium acnes, and Moraxella

Clinical Features
  • Chronic irritation
  • Itching
  • Mild lacrimation
  • Gluing of cilia
  • Mild photophobia
  • Yellow crusts at the root of cilia
  • Small ulcers that bleed easily when crusts are removed
  • Red, thickened lid margins with dilated blood vessels
  • Mild papillary conjunctivitis and conjunctival hyperemia

Treatment
  • Lid Hygiene:
    • Warm compresses
    • Cotton buds dipped in dilute baby shampoo or 3% sodium bicarbonate solution
    • Avoid touching
  • Antibiotics
  • Topical Steroids
  • Ocular Lubricants

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl has been having difficulty opening her left eye since birth. An image is given below. What is the condition?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Definition

Etiology

Symblepharon

Palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva adhesions.
  • Healing of raw surfaces on the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva.
  • Causes: Thermal or chemical burns, membranous conjunctivitis, injuries, conjunctival ulcerations, ocular pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Ankyloblepharon

Adhesions between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids.
  • Congenital anomaly.
  • Acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, thermal burns, ulcers, and traumatic wounds of the lid margins.
  • Often associated with symblepharon.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism is now complaining of loss of eyelashes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Definition

Local Causes

Systemic Causes

Madarosis (Option A)

Partial or complete loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.
  • Chronic blepharitis
  • Cicatrizing conjunctivitis
  • Complications from cryotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgery for eyelid lesions
  • Alopecia
  • Psoriasis
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Leprosy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Acquired syphilis

Poliosis (Option B)

Greying of eyelashes and eyebrows.
  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis
  • Idiopathic uveitis
  • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome
  • Waardenburg syndrome
  • Vitiligo
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: A neonatologist has noted the following finding in a newborn baby. What is the condition called?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Photophobia
  • Irritation
  • Pain
  • Lacrimation
  • Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded)
  • Conjunctival congestion

Complications
  • Recurrent corneal abrasions
  • Superficial corneal opacities
  • Corneal vascularization
  • Non-healing corneal ulcer

Treatment
  • Epilation
  • Electrolysis
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with complaints of epiphora. On examination, there is an eversion of the punctum noted. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the type of ectropion seen in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Age-related changes are implicated in etiopathogenesis

options.label: D
options.text: Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

questions.correct_answer: D. Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially
questions.explanation:
Type of Ectropion

Description

Causes

Clinical Features

Treatment

Involutional Ectropion
  • Most common; age-related
  • Horizontal laxity
  • Canthal tendon laxity
  • Epiphora
  • Tarsal thinning
  • Lagophthalmos
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases.
  • Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases.
  • Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases.
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion.

Cicatricial Ectropion
  • Scarring of anterior lamella
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis)
  • Scarring
  • Skin fibrosis
  • Mild cases: V-Y operation.
  • Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation).
  • Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting.

Paralytic Ectropion
  • Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s)
  • Bell’s palsy
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.
  • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation.

Mechanical Ectropion
  • Mass or lesion pushing eyelid
  • Tumors
  • Conjunctival growths
  • Eyelid displacement
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Treat the underlying mechanical causes.

Congenital Ectropion
  • Present at birth
  • Tarsal plate atrophy
  • Down syndrome
  • Associated eyelid malformation
  • Mild cases may not require treatment.
  • Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft.

GRADE

FEATURE

0

Normal eyelid appearance and function

I

Only punctum is everted

II

Lid margin everted and palpebral conjunctiva visible

III

Fornix is also visible

questions.text: Match the following types of entropion with their correct pair 1) Mechanical entropion A) Trachoma 2) Cicatricial entropion B) Phthisis bulbi 3) Congenital entropion C) Senile entropion 4) Involutional entropion D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid
questions.explanation:
1) Mechanical entropion

B) Phthisis bulbi

2) Cicatricial entropion

A) Trachoma

3) Congenital entropion

D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid

4) Involutional entropion

C) Senile entropion

Type

Description

Etiology

1) Congenital Entropion

Present since birth, more common in the lower eyelid

  • Lower Eyelid: Improper development of lower lid retractors.
  • Upper Eyelid: Mechanical effects due to microphthalmos.

2) Cicatricial Entropion

Commonly involves the upper eyelid.



 
  • Common causes: Trachoma, chemical burns, pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, symblepharon.

3) Senile (Involutional) Entropion

Affects the lower eyelid in elderly individuals.
  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis.
  • Laxity of orbital septum

4) Mechanical Entropion

Lack of support from the globe to the lids.
  • Occurs in conditions like phthisis bulbi, enophthalmos and after enucleation or evisceration operations.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient presents with the following ocular findings and complaints of watering and photophobia. On examination, there are signs of minimal horizontal lid laxity. Which of the following surgical procedures would be the most appropriate for a long-term correction of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Description and etiology
  • Usually seen in lower eyelid in elderly people
  • Horizontal lid laxity due to weakening of orbicularis muscle
  • Vertical lid instability due to weakening of capsulopalpebral fascia
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis/Laxity of orbital septum

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Horizontal lid laxity

Surgical Techniques

i. Transverse Suture and Everting Suture: (Option A)

  • Temporary cure (up to 18 months)
  • Suitable for very old patients

ii. Weis procedure: (Option B)

  • Long-term cure with minimal horizontal lid laxity

iii. Plication of Lower Lid Retractors (Jones Operation): (Option C)

  • Used in severe cases or after recurrence
  • Shortens lower lid retractors.

iv. Quickert Procedure: (Option D)

  • For cases with marked horizontal lid laxity
  • Combines horizontal lid shortening with Weis procedure

Grade-I

Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled

Grade-II

includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip

Grade-III

Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled

questions.text: Which among the following structures is part of the anterior lamella of the eyelid?
All are causes of ipsilateral pseudoptosis except
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral pseudoptosis

Contralateral pseudoptosis
  • Microphthalmos
  • Enophthalmos (Option A)
  • Phthisis bulbi (Option D)
  • Hypotropia (Option C)
  • Dermatochalasis
  • Eyelid retraction (Option B)
  • High myopia
  • Proptosis

questions.text: Which of the following measurements is considered indicative of moderate ptosis?
questions.explanation:
Mild Ptosis

2mm droop

Moderate Ptosis

3mm droop

Severe Ptosis

4mm droop

questions.text: Which muscle is most commonly affected in congenital ptosis?
Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of aponeurotic ptosis compared to other forms of ptosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Presents with normal function of the levator muscle

options.label: C
options.text: Results from a neurological condition affecting the third cranial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Usually involves a sudden onset of symptoms

questions.correct_answer: B. Presents with normal function of the levator muscle

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with bilateral ptosis that worsens throughout the day, particularly in the evening, and improves with rest. She also complains of double vision and generalized fatigue. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 60-year old male, heavy smoker, presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to arm for several months. He presents with the following ocular findings. A chest x-ray reveals mass at the apex of the left lung. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to accompany this patient?
Identify the structure marked ‘X’ in the given image.
questions.explanation:
Anterior lamella

Posterior lamella
  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Tarsal plate
  • Conjunctiva
